channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills 3 in Nigeria
item.description: A suicide bomber killed at least three people Saturday in an attack on a market in northeast Nigeria, police and civilian vigilante sources said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Deadly Gunfire Traded in Kashmir
item.description: The Indian and Pakistani armies each blamed the other for the violence that killed at least four civilians in the disputed Himalayan region.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 40 Migrants Found Dead in Sea Rescue
item.description: At least 40 migrants died on an overcrowded smuggling boat north of Libya, and about 320 others aboard were saved by the Italian Navy.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Wolves, Resurgent and Protected, Vex Swedish Farmers
item.description: With a wolf population that is resurgent and now protected, Sweden has a conflict that pits farmers and hunters against environmentalists and European officials, who object to culling the animals.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: David Magnusson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ulf Ekholm on his farm in Olmhult, in a region of Sweden called Varmland. He and other farmers fear for their sheep because of the increasing numbers of wolves.

item.title: A North Korean Defector’s Regret
item.description: Kim Ryen-hi, a 45-year-old dressmaker from North Korea, says that her defection to South Korea four years ago was a terrible mistake, and that she has been trying to return to be with her family.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Ryen-hi, who left North Korea four years ago, says her defection was a mistake. She now works at a recycling plant, operating a machine that chops up wires.

item.title: Libya Seeks Airstrikes Against ISIS Branch
item.description: At least 46 people were killed in recent days in clashes among the Libyan branch of the Islamic State, a rival Islamist group and forces loyal to the internationally recognized government in two Libyan cities, residents and medics say.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Brooklyn Man Accused of Supporting ISIS Pleads Guilty
item.description: Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev, 25, who admitted to plotting to provide material to the Islamic State terrorist group, could face up to 15 years in prison.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: Editorial: Ugly Attacks on Refugees in Europe
item.description: With resentment against new arrivals growing, European nations must do more to help Greece and Italy cope.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:credit: Daniel Etter for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man prays after arriving on the island of Kos, Greece, on Thursday.

item.title: Emperor Akihito Expresses ‘Deep Remorse’ for Japan’s Role in World War II
item.description: Emperor Akihito, whose father announced his exhausted country’s surrender in World War II 70 years ago, expressed “deep remorse” for the conflict on Saturday at a memorial service marking the anniversary of the war’s end.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: People released doves at the Yasukuni shrine in Tokyo on Saturday, the 70th anniversary of Japan’s surrender in World War II.

item.title: For French-Algerians and Algerian-French, No Place to Truly Call Home
item.description: A century-long ebb and flow of migrants has created a population of Franco-Algerians and Algerian-French whom neither country fully embraces.
item.dc:creator: AMIR JALAL ZERDOUMI
item.media:credit: Kosuke Okahara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amine Benkerri, 37, left, and Karim Beghache, 22, in Saint-Denis, a suburb of Paris. Both are French citizens of Algerian descent.

item.title: Red Cross Offers Workshops in International Law to Hamas
item.description: The Red Cross developed its program in conjunction with Islamic scholars. So far this year, it has conducted six sessions for a total of 210 fighters from Hamas’s Izzedine al-Qassam Brigades and two other Gaza armed groups
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Izzedine al-Qassam Brigades, the military wing of Hamas, in Gaza this month.

item.title: Tianjin Officials Struggle to Contain Fallout as Angry Relatives Demand Answers
item.description: A news conference in Tianjin was stormed by distraught relatives holding up lists of names, demanding information about dozens of missing firefighters.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: South Korean Leader Marks Anniversary of War’s End With Warnings to North Korea
item.description: Commemorating what South Koreans call Liberation Day, President Park Geun-hye said “provocations” from the North would “lead only to isolation and destruction.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye urged North Korea on Saturday to learn from Cuba’s moves to improve relations with the United States, saying the North had been “walking in the other direction.”

item.title: ISIS Held Kayla Mueller, U.S. Aid Worker, as Sex Slave Before Fatal Airstrike
item.description: Details of Ms. Mueller’s captivity, including her repeated rape by the leader of the Islamic State, were pieced together by American officials.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Matt Hinshaw/The Daily Courier, via Associated Press

item.title: ISIS Is Suspected of a Chemical Attack Against Kurds in Syria
item.description: If verified, the use of chemical agents could increase pressure on the Obama administration to intervene in the war more forcefully.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Police Suspected in Killings of 18
item.description: The Authorities in São Paulo said Friday that they were investigating whether police officers were involved in a series of execution-style killings.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Kerry Strikes Delicate Balance in Havana Trip for Embassy Flag-Raising
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry attended a ceremony at the diplomatic post, which officially opened in July, before talking to dissidents at a separate reception.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry greeted the Marines who had lowered the flag at the United States Embassy in Havana in 1961.

item.title: Open Source: Internet Hoax on Downing of Malaysian Jet Spreads in Russia
item.description: In audio posted online this week by a Russian newspaper, a man identified as an American reporter working for the C.I.A. speaks in a British accent.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S.-Led Air Campaign Is Linked to Civilian Deaths in Syria
item.description: The episode revived accusations that the United States and its allies are not careful enough about who is killed by airstrikes on militant groups.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.media:description: Damage at a weapons factory operated by rebel fighters that was targeted in what activists said were American-led airstrikes on Atmeh, a Syrian village near the Turkish border.

item.title: Russian Publisher Rewrites Books on Putin Without Western Authors’ Consent
item.description: Western authors are finding that new versions of their books about Russia are appearing in bookstores there — rewritten and released without their permission.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:description: Luke Harding, a British journalist whose book was rewritten without his permission by a Russian publisher.
